API reference¶

Atom¶

class atom.Atom(num=0, nam='ND', x=0.0, y=0.0, z=0.0, typ='ND')[source]¶

A class to store the coordinates (x,y,z) and other atom properties.

  • Parm num (int): Atom number.
  • Parm nam (int): Atom name.
  • Parm x (float): Atom x coordinate.
  • Parm y (float): Atom y coordinate.
  • Parm z (float): Atom name.
  • Parm typ (Atom): Atom type (element)

Note

Initializing an Atom object with arguments is optional.

>>> O = Atom(121, 'OH', 13.015, 20.145, 21.457, 'O')
copy¶

Returns a deepcopy of Atom object.

>>> O = Atom(num=121, x=13.015, y=20.145, z=21.457, typ='O')
>>> H = O.copy
>>> O.show
[121, 'ND', 13.015, 20.145, 21.457, 'O']
>>> H.show
[121, 'ND', 13.015, 20.145, 21.457, 'O']
>>> H = Atom(num=12, x=13.015, y=20.145, z=21.457, typ='H')
>>> O.show
[121, 'ND', 13.015, 20.145, 21.457, 'O']
>>> H.show
[12, 'ND', 13.015, 20.145, 21.457, 'H']

Note

A variable assignment only creates another link to the same object. If you wish to create a new object, use copy function.

>>> H = Atom(num=1,typ='H')
>>> O = H
>>> O.typ = 'O'
>>> O.num = 2
>>> H.show
[2, 'ND', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'O']
cord¶

Sets/Returns coordinates.

>>> O = Atom()
>>> O.cord = [3.015, 20.145, 21.457]
>>> x, y, z = O.cord
>>> print(x,y,z)
3.015 20.145 21.457
>>> O.cord = [13.000, 20.145, 21.457]
>>> O.cord
[13.0, 20.145, 21.457]
>>> xyz = O.cord
>>> xyz
[13.0, 20.145, 21.457]
nam¶

Sets/Returns atom name.

>>> O = Atom()
>>> O.nam
'ND'
>>> O.nam = 'OG'
>>> O.nam
'OG'
num¶

Sets/Returns atom number.

>>> O = Atom()
>>> O.num
0
>>> O.num = '10'
>>> O.num
10
show¶

Returns num, nam, x, y, z, typ.

>>> O = Atom(num=121, x=13.015, y=20.145, z=21.457, typ='O')
>>> O.show
[121, 'ND', 13.015, 20.145, 21.457, 'O']
tolerance = 1e-05¶
typ¶

Sets/Returns atom type.

>>> O = Atom()
>>> O.typ
'ND'
>>> O.typ = 'O'
>>> O.typ
'O'
>>> print(O.typ)
O

Molecule¶

class molecule.Molecule(num=0, nam=None, atms=None, head=None, tail=None, pos=None, chainnum=None, chainnam=None)[source]¶

A class to store a collection of Atom objects. This class is iterable.

  • Parm num (int): Molecule number.
  • Parm nam (str): Molecule name.
  • Parm atms (Atom): List of atoms in the molecule.
  • Parm natm (int): Number of atoms in the molecule
  • Parm head (Atom): The head atom in the molecule. Used for connecting residues.
  • Parm tail (Atom): The tail atom in the molecule. Used for connecting residues.
  • Parm pos (str): The position of the molecule in a macromolecule (FIRST or LAST). Used for connecting residues.
  • Parm chainnum (int): Molecule chain number.
  • Parm chainnam (str): Molecule chain name

Note

Initializing a Molecule object with arguments is optional. It is possible to initialize a molecule object by one or a list of atom object. Number of atoms (natm) is set automatically.

>>> O  = Atom()
>>> O4 = [Atom(num=1), Atom(num=2), Atom(num=3), Atom(num=4)]
>>> molecule_O  = Molecule(num=1, atms=O)
>>> molecule_O4 = Molecule(num=1, atms=O4)
>>> for index, atom in enumerate(molecule_O4):
...  print(index, '-', atom.num)
0 - 1
1 - 2
2 - 3
3 - 4
addatm(atm)[source]¶

Appends atom(s) object to a molecule

>>> H1, O = Atom(typ='H'), Atom(typ='O')
>>> H2 = H1.copy
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1,nam='HOH')
>>> HOH.addatm(H1)
>>> HOH.addatm(H2)
>>> HOH.show
[1, 'HOH', 2]
>>> HOH.addatm(O)
>>> HOH.show
[1, 'HOH', 3]

Note

addatm appends a hard copy of input variables.

>>> H1 = Atom(num=1,typ='H')
>>> H2 = Atom(num=1,typ='H')
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1,nam='HH')
>>> HOH.addatm([H1, H2])
>>> print([[atom.num, atom.typ] for atom in HOH])
[[1, 'H'], [1, 'H']]
>>> H1.num = 500
>>> print([[atom.num, atom.typ] for atom in HOH])
[[1, 'H'], [1, 'H']]
chainnam¶

Returns/Sets chain name that molecule belongs to.

>>> HOH = Molecule()
>>> HOH.chainnam
>>>
>>> HOH.chainnam = 'A'
>>> HOH.chainnam
'A'
chainnum¶

Returns/Sets chain number that molecule belongs to.

>>> HOH = Molecule()
>>> HOH.chainnum
>>>
>>> HOH.chainnum = 10
>>> HOH.chainnum
10
copy¶

Returns a deepcopy of Molecule object.

>>> HOH1 = Molecule(num=1, nam='HOH')
>>> HOH2 = HOH1.copy
>>> HOH2.show
[1, 'HOH', 0]
>>> HOH2.num = 2
>>> HOH2.show
[2, 'HOH', 0]
>>> HOH1.show
[1, 'HOH', 0]
head¶

Sets/Returns Molecule head atom. The Molecule.head accepts an Atom, a str, or an int. If an Atom object is given, it should exist in the molecule otherwise a ValueError is raised. If a str or an int is given, the atoms in the molecule are searched for a unique match and Molecule.head points to that. If multiple values was found an ValueError exception is raised.

>>> ATOMS = [Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='O')]
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1, nam='HOH', atms=ATOMS)
>>> print(HOH.head)
None
>>> HOH.head = HOH.selectbyAtomnum(1)
>>> HOH.head.show
[1, 'H1', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
>>> print((HOH.head) is HOH.selectbyAtomnum(1))
True

Here the head function tries to find an Atom that is equal to the input and assigns the head to that. In other word, the head Atom always points to an atom that belongs to the molecule, even if, the input Atom does not belong to the molecule.

>>> HOH.head = ATOMS[0]
>>> print((HOH.head) is HOH.selectbyAtomnum(1))
True
>>> print(HOH.head == ATOMS[0])
True
>>> print(HOH.head is ATOMS[0])
False
>>> HOH.head = 'H2'
>>> HOH.head.show
[2, 'H2', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
>>> HOH.head = 3
>>> HOH.head.show
[3, 'O', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
>>> try:
...     HOH.head = 23
... except Exception as error:
...     print(error)
The input Atom number either was not found or has multiple occurrences
nam¶

Sets/Returns Molecule number.

>>> HOH = Molecule()
>>> HOH.nam

>>> HOH.nam = 'HOH'
>>> HOH.nam
'HOH'
natm¶

Returns number of atoms in a molecule.

>>> O4 = [Atom(), Atom(), Atom(), Atom()]
>>> molecule_O4 = Molecule(num=1, atms=O4)
>>> molecule_O4.natm
4
num¶

Sets/Returns Molecule number.

>>> HOH = Molecule()
>>> HOH.num
0
>>> HOH.num = 12
>>> HOH.num
12
pos¶

Sets/Returns the position of the molecule in a Macromolecule. Could be set to “FIRST” or “LAST” for first or last residue in a chain.

>>> HOH = Molecule(Atom(num=1), Atom(num=2), Atom(num=3))
>>> HOH.pos
>>>
>>> HOH.pos = 'FIRST'
>>> if HOH.pos is 'FIRST': print('First residue')
First residue
selectbyAtomnam(name)[source]¶

Returns a Atom or a list of Atom with the given Atom.nam. If only one Atom, was found and Atom object is returned. Otherwise a list of Atom objects is returned.

>>> ATOMS = [Atom(nam='HC'), Atom(nam='HC'), Atom(nam='O')]
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1, nam='HOH', atms=ATOMS)
>>> select = HOH.selectbyAtomnam('HC')
>>> [atom.show for atom in select]
[[0, 'HC', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND'], [0, 'HC', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']]
selectbyAtomnum(number)[source]¶

Returns a Atom or a list of Atom with the given Atom.num. If only one Atom, was found and Atom object is returned. Otherwise a list of Atom objects is returned.

>>> ATOMS = [Atom(num=1), Atom(num=2), Atom(num=3)]
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1, nam='HOH', atms=ATOMS)
>>> select = HOH.selectbyAtomnum(1)
>>> select.show
[1, 'ND', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
show¶

Returns num, nam, natm.

>>> H, O = Atom(typ='H'), Atom(typ='O')
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1,nam='HOH', atms=[H, H, O])
>>> HOH.show
[1, 'HOH', 3]
tail¶

Sets/Returns Molecule tail atom. The Molecule.tail accepts an Atom, a str, or an int. If an Atom object is given, it should exist in the molecule otherwise a ValueError is raised (see Molecule.head). If a str or an int is given, the atoms in the molecule are searched for a unique match and Molecule.head points to that. If multiple values was found an ValueError exception is raised.

>>> ATOMS = [Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='O')]
>>> HOH = Molecule(num=1, nam='HOH', atms=ATOMS)
>>> print(HOH.tail)
None
>>> HOH.tail = HOH.selectbyAtomnum(1)
>>> HOH.tail.show
[1, 'H1', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
>>> HOH.tail = 'H2'
>>> HOH.tail.show
[2, 'H2', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
>>> HOH.tail = 3
>>> HOH.tail.show
[3, 'O', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
>>> try:
...     HOH.tail = 23
... except Exception as error:
...     print(error)
The input Atom number either was not found or has multiple occurrences

Macromolecule¶

class macromolecule.Macromolecule(nam=None, mols=None)[source]¶
A class to store a collection of Molecule objects.
  • Parm nam (str): Molecule name.
  • Parm mols (Atom): List of atoms in the molecule.

Todo

Under construction

Note

Initializing a Macromolecule object with arguments is optional. It is possible to initialize a Macromolecule object by one or a list of molecule object. Number of molecules (nmol) is set automatically.

>>> reslist = [Molecule(num=1,nam='ARG'), Molecule(num=1,nam='ALA'), Molecule(num=1,nam='GLY'),]
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1', mols=reslist)
addmol(mol)[source]¶

Appends a hard copy of Molecule object(s) to a Macromolecule object.

>>> res1, res2, res3 = Molecule(num=1,nam='ARG'), Molecule(num=1,nam='ALA'), Molecule(num=1,nam='GLY')
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1')
>>> peptide.show
['peptide A1', 0]
>>> peptide.addmol(res1)
>>> peptide.addmol([res2, res3])
>>> peptide.show
['peptide A1', 3]
atoms¶

Returns the list of atoms in a Macromolecule

>>> res1 = Molecule(num=1, atms=[Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='H3')])
>>> res2 = Molecule(num=2, atms=[Atom(num=4, nam='O1'), Atom(num=5, nam='O2'), Atom(num=6, nam='O3')])
>>> res3 = Molecule(num=3, atms=[Atom(num=7, nam='N1'), Atom(num=8, nam='N2'), Atom(num=9, nam='N3')])
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1', mols=[res1, res2, res3])
>>>
>>> [[atom.num, atom.nam] for atom in peptide.atoms]
[[1, 'H1'], [2, 'H2'], [3, 'H3'], [4, 'O1'], [5, 'O2'], [6, 'O3'], [7, 'N1'], [8, 'N2'], [9, 'N3']]
copy¶

Returns a deepcopy of Macromolecule object.

nmol¶

Returns number of Molecule in a Macromolecule

>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='A1', mols=[Molecule(num=1), Molecule(num=2), Molecule(num=3)])
>>> peptide.nmol
3
selectbyAtomnam(name)[source]¶

Returns a Atom or a list of Atom with the given Atom.nam. If only one Atom was found, an Atom object is returned. Otherwise a list of Atom objects is returned.

>>> res1 = Molecule(num=1, nam='res1', atms=[Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='H3')])
>>> res2 = Molecule(num=2, nam='res2', atms=[Atom(num=4, nam='O1'), Atom(num=5, nam='O2'), Atom(num=6, nam='O3')])
>>> res3 = Molecule(num=3, nam='res3', atms=[Atom(num=7, nam='N1'), Atom(num=8, nam='N2'), Atom(num=9, nam='N3')])
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1', mols=[res1, res2, res3])
>>> peptide.selectbyAtomnam('O1').show
[4, 'O1', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
selectbyAtomnum(number)[source]¶

Returns a Atom or a list of Atom with the given Atom.num. If only one Atom was found, an Atom object is returned. Otherwise a list of Atom objects is returned.

>>> res1 = Molecule(num=1, nam='res1', atms=[Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='H3')])
>>> res2 = Molecule(num=2, nam='res2', atms=[Atom(num=4, nam='O1'), Atom(num=5, nam='O2'), Atom(num=6, nam='O3')])
>>> res3 = Molecule(num=3, nam='res3', atms=[Atom(num=7, nam='N1'), Atom(num=8, nam='N2'), Atom(num=9, nam='N3')])
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1', mols=[res1, res2, res3])
>>> peptide.selectbyAtomnum(9).show
[9, 'N3', 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 'ND']
selectbyMolnam(name)[source]¶

Returns a Molecule or a list of Molecule with the given Molecule.nam. If only one Molecule was found, an Molecule object is returned. Otherwise a list of Molecule objects is returned.

>>> res1 = Molecule(num=1, nam='res1', atms=[Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='H3')])
>>> res2 = Molecule(num=2, nam='res2', atms=[Atom(num=4, nam='O1'), Atom(num=5, nam='O2'), Atom(num=6, nam='O3')])
>>> res3 = Molecule(num=3, nam='res3', atms=[Atom(num=7, nam='N1'), Atom(num=8, nam='N2'), Atom(num=9, nam='N3')])
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1', mols=[res1, res2, res3])
>>> peptide.selectbyMolnam('res2').show
[2, 'res2', 3]
selectbyMolnum(number)[source]¶

Returns a Molecule or a list of Molecule with the given Molecule.num. If only one Molecule was found, an Molecule object is returned. Otherwise a list of Molecule objects is returned.

>>> res1 = Molecule(num=1, nam='res1', atms=[Atom(num=1, nam='H1'), Atom(num=2, nam='H2'), Atom(num=3, nam='H3')])
>>> res2 = Molecule(num=2, nam='res1', atms=[Atom(num=4, nam='O1'), Atom(num=5, nam='O2'), Atom(num=6, nam='O3')])
>>> res3 = Molecule(num=3, nam='res1', atms=[Atom(num=7, nam='N1'), Atom(num=8, nam='N2'), Atom(num=9, nam='N3')])
>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='peptide A1', mols=[res1, res2, res3])
>>> peptide.selectbyMolnum(1).show
[1, 'res1', 3]
show¶

Returns nam, nmol.

>>> peptide = Macromolecule(nam='A2', mols=[Molecule(), Molecule(), Molecule()])
>>> peptide.show
['A2', 3]

parse_qm¶

class parse_qm.OptG09(ifile)[source]¶

A class to read and save G09 optimization output. This class inherits from Macromolecule. This class assumes the given file exists and is G09 optimization output. Use the ParseGaussian if error management is needed.

parse_opt_g09(ifile)[source]¶
class parse_qm.ParseGaussian(ifile)[source]¶

This class reads the header section of a Gaussian output and initiate a corresponding parser class.

getheader(ifile)[source]¶

Checks input file header for Gaussian version and command line options

parse_qm.parseQM(ifile, program)[source]¶

This is a wrapper function for classes that parse the QM calculations output files

atom_table¶

atom_table.atom_property(query, target, value)[source]¶

returns the atomic property (query) based on the given atomic property (traget) with a given value (value)

  • parm query: needed atomic property
  • parm target: given atomic property
  • parm value: the value of given atomic property
>>> print(atom_property(query='symbol', target='number', value=25))
Mn
>>> print(atom_property(query='mass', target='number', value=25))
54.93805
